name: Kepler-381
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-381 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-381 is a star with 2.0299999999999994 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.57 times its radius. It is located 878.63 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-381 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-381 b

Kepler-381 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.63 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-381.

The mass of Kepler-381 b is 0.93 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-381 b is 0.99 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-381 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-381 c

Kepler-381 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.39 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-381.

The mass of Kepler-381 c is 1.27 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-381 c is 1.12 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-381 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-381, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
